data.title: Wheeler Dealers’ Mike Brewer furious after being ‘scammed’ by buyer and forced to repay
data.meta_description: Wheeler Dealers star Mike Brewer may have been 'scammed' by a possible buyer in a major blow.
data.text:
Wheeler Dealers TV host Mike Brewer has claimed he has been “scammed” by a buyer and has possibly lost thousands.

The presenter of the popular classic car restoration programme revealed a buyer had used fake information to purchase a vehicle in a simple crime.

However, this led to a whole host of problems with Mike possibly losing the vehicle and the profits.

He informed his fans about the problem in a message on social media site X and uploaded a video explaining more.

He said: “We think we’ve been scammed not only once but possibly twice. Once by a customer who scammed somebody with their ID to buy a car but the second time quite possibly by the car provider.”

READ MORE Wheeler Dealers star predicts ‘modern classic’ will soon be worth ‘10 grand’

Mike explained how his One Automotive group had advertised a white VW Golf Mk7 GTD for just over £10,000.

He stressed there was initially lots of interest in the car but things quickly went downhill.

An interested motorist rang up to enquire about the car and quickly offered to buy the vehicle.

However, as they were not based locally, the buyer instead arranged a collection service to pick up the vehicle at Mike’s Leamington Spa base.

Mike admitted that before letting the vehicle go they ran various checks on the buyer's personal information to process the sale.

DON'T MISS

Wheeler Dealers host claims common Ford will be 'future classic' within years [LATEST]

Wheeler Dealers’ host says top used car is ‘bulletproof’ cheap vehicle [ANALYSIS]

Wheeler Dealers ‘decay’ warning to all classic car owners over summer error [COMMENT]

But, the buyer's driving licence “checked out” and the bank details provided appeared to be legitimate.

The individual was quickly invoiced with the courier arriving soon later to pick up the model for collection.

However, Mike was quickly contacted by his own bank provider who revealed the person charged for the vehicle had disputed the sale.

He explained: “They tell us this chap has opened up his statement and he’s seen he has paid for a car at One Automotive and it wasn't him.

Invalid email

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

“He’s been scammed by somebody who has stolen his ID and stolen his card details and used that to buy a car from me and James at One Automotive.”

But, things got worse for Mike with the TV host claiming he was being forced to repay the money to refund the individual.

He added: “We did everything we could do. We did our due diligence. We checked the card, checked the names and addresses and did everything we possibly could do.

“And somehow now we get a reverse charge so we’ve now lost not only the car but the money as well. We are not at fault.”
